Summary

Today I dedicated time to schedule meetings for this week and the following week. I completed Zybook reading of Chapter 3 - Sets. I took notes of the material and noticed areas for improvement.

For my life hacking I tested waking up at 7am, logging of daily tasks and using pomodoro’s in emacs to remind me of when to take breaks.

Problem

I noticed I setup two 120min focus blocks, one for each one of my classes without any recovery period in between. This then leads to exhaustion and frustration. This is a marathon. I need to change my perspective and interpret graduate school more as a distance runner, as a swimming and pace myself accordingly and adapt.

During the Zybook I experienced some difficulty with Set operations that are complex and being able to determine in a Venn diagram the shaded region a complex set operation.

Insight

I will incorporate additional recovery blocks in between my sessions. Practicing thinking and moving slower to gain clarity of mind when learning a new concept / idea. The complex set operations, particular identifying regions can be done if each part of the set operation is broken down to it’s individual simple part and doing it step by step rather than trying to visualize it the entire process in one go.

I must protect my mind, similar to a garden and nurture it. To this end I have to change my schedule in Google Calendar so that it’s a reflection of my natural starting/stopping points. As of now when I have an agenda item/task that I don’t complete in a given time-frame/box I feel negative emotions about my performance. I can redefine what success look like for me. I can change and adapt to circumstances.

The midterm is approaching. I need to start reviewing and creating a strategy of how to best prepare each exam.

Tomorrow

  • To complete Homework assignment #3 for CS5002 and
  • To review sets for tomorrow’s lecture

Dedicated time today to CS5001. Starting my initial review of programming problems from the homework, completing defining the functions and almost complete with the test cases and preparing for the last portion of the assignment where I’m putting it all together.

Problem

Estimating the amount of time it takes to complete a task. Sometimes I may allocate 30min or so for a given task and then I’m consumed by the task and want to spend more time with it and then not dedicating enough time for other tasks.The proper optimal distribution of times for a given task to push a brick forward.

Before starting a task I estimate the amount of time it will take me to complete the given task. This deliberate planning of estimating my time and logging has kept me focused and accountable.

Problem

For CS5001, I allocated some time this morning making sure style was correct, test cases, and generally good for submission. A good chunk of time trying to setup latex to play nicely with emacs. I experienced some difficulty with the financial aid office and I’m waiting to hear back.

Insight

To start homework assignments earlier and focus on completing them. I will start using emacs to calculate the amount of effort it takes to complete a given task.

Doing Despite Disliking: Self-regulatory Strategies in Everyday Aversive Activities

Abstract: We investigated the self-regulatory strategies people spontaneously use in their everyday lives to regulate their persistence during aversive activities. In pilot studies (pooled N = 794), we identified self-regulatory strategies from self-reports and generated hypotheses about individual differences in trait self-control predicting their use. Next, deploying ambulatory assessment (N = 264, 1940 reports of aversive/challenging activities), we investigated predictors of the strategiesself-reported use and effectiveness (trait self-control and demand types). The popularity of strategies varied across demands. In addition, people higher in trait self-control were more likely to focus on the positive consequences of a given activity, set goals, and use emotion regulation. Focusing on positive consequences, focusing on negative consequences (of not performing the activity), thinking of the near finish, and emotion regulation increased perceived self-regulatory success across demands, whereas distracting oneself from the aversive activity decreased it. None of these strategies, however, accounted for the beneficial effects of trait self-control on perceived self-regulatory success. Hence, trait self-control and strategy use appear to represent separate routes to good self-regulation. By considering trait- and process-approaches these findings promote a more comprehensive understanding of self-regulatory success and failure during peoples daily attempts to regulate their persistence. 2018 European Association of Personality Psychology

Tomorrow

To review this week’s material from both CS5001 and CS5001 classes and to marinate the homework released for each class.

Summary

Woke up early to the YMCA to swim and had two meetings with my health care providers. I re-looked at change.py and was able to come up with a working solution in the afternoon. Then later had night classes.

Problem

change.py took some time to work on while the other homework problems I was able to complete in a moderately fast time. I believe the lesson learned here, it’s not quite about speed, but focusing more on planning and making sure I have a draft on paper before I start my second draft on a computer. In addition, I realized that I was feeling exhausted the whole day at different times by the time late afternoon arrived.

Insight

When working on a programming problem, regardless of how easy I may perceive the problem to be, start on paper first to at least have an idea. Other thoughts are to possibly change my morning routine so I’m not waking up at 6am everyday, but perhaps the night I have classes I can wake up later.

Tomorrow

To review homework before submission for both classes and review material from CS5001 in preparation for lab

I re-looked at change.py and was able to come up with a working solution in the afternoon. Then later had night classes.
Problem change.py took some time to work on while the other homework problems I was able to complete in a moderately fast time. I believe the lesson learned here, it’s not quite about speed, but focusing more on planning and making sure I have a draft on paper before I start my second draft on a computer. In addition, I realized that I was feeling exhausted the whole day at different times by the time late afternoon arrived.
Insight When working on a programming problem, regardless of how easy I may perceive the problem to be, start on paper first to at least have an idea. Other thoughts are to possibly change my morning routine so I’m not waking up at 6am everyday, but perhaps the night I have classes I can wake up later.
Tomorrow To review homework before submission for both classes and review material from CS5001 in preparation for lab

Summary

Spent the majority of today working on change.py and completing the Zybook reading. I was able to complete the Zybook reading and make progress on change.py. There was some level of friction due to not starting this specific problem on paper.

Problem

Part of the difficulty that I noticed in completing change.py was that I didn’t first attempt to solve it on a piece of paper, but rather jumped into emacs and tried to solve it. Doing it this approach took me a much longer time than anticipated.

Insight

Make sure I have a general schema, outline, notes, worked out the solution somewhat on paper and then on a computer. Using a computer and programming it is equivalent to a second or third draft of writing, in this case code.

Tomorrow

Will take time to review the problem, review test cases, syntax and general style. Will see if I have the time to do office hours.

For CS5002 I will use supplementary sources to review material and in preparation for the upcoming lecture.

content.html:
While I was hospitalized for close to two years, the first trip that I made to society was to visit Northeastern University in one of their college tours for prospective students. At the time when I was hospitalized, I was learning Python, and I didnt have reliable access to a computer. In times I didnt have access to a computer, I printed pages from a PDF and took notes on scratch paper that nurses gave me.

I feel immense pride to say years later I was accepted to Northeastern University. Im honored to be the first in my family to be admitted to graduate school. Im a neurodivergent, person of color, Latino pursuing my masters degree in Computer Science. With all that being said I have not done well in my graduate classes. I was unaware of the level of rigor required for the program while also working full-time as a high school teacher compounded with lifes challenges and my own habits, emotions and insecurities.

In this website, I will document my learning path and my process to hold myself accountable for reaching my goal of attaining my masters degree in Computer Science.

  • In the Now section you can see my objectives for today, this week, month and year.
  • The Review section consists of a daily and weekly review, a micro-level look at my day including time stamps and a table with a summary of time spent on a given task.
  • The Courses section will contain courses that I am currently taking or have in the past with links to notes taken on the topics presented in the class.
  • The Notes section consists of my notes taken about a subject matter. The notes will be used to create lessons to be made accessible to a broader audience.

If you have any comments or suggestions, please feel free to contact me.

content.html:
Im a graduate student at Northeastern Universitys ALIGN program pursuing a masters degree in Computer Science. The ALIGN program consists of a series of bridge courses for graduate students who didnt major in Computer Science in their undergraduate studies. Upon completion of the ALIGN program students begin taking graduate level classes in computer science.

Attaining a masters degree in computer science will link my community experience with technology and leverage this knowledge to contribute to the self-development and self-sufficiency of communities of color, as well as to enhance peoples capacities to solve problems. My long-term goal is to create a co-operative of social justice focused technologists, Technology for Communities, which specializes in civic technology to assist community organizations by assessing needs, analyzing data and creating solutions. A computer science degree combined with my collective experience as a community organizer will allow me to use technology collaboratively with organizations and individuals to address needs to strengthen communities and amplify our collective voice.

content.html:
From about 2012 to 2014 I was hospitalized due to my mental health. This period was one of the most painful and challenging times for me in my life: being away from friends, family, and society. I was completely excluded from participating in society both physically and mentally, an outcast. I longed to walk in the city, to see my friends and family, to continue my education and to be involved in a community. Upon my release in 2014, I had to restart my life.

I reconnected with friends and started volunteering in different non-profits in the Boston area. My efforts in volunteering eventually lead me to the opportunity of being an AmeriCorps member for United Way. I along with others focused on providing services to residents in Lynn, MA. In my year of service, I served at a high school: supporting students and teachers, creating an afterschool program, being a positive role model and providing support and services to the community. Around the same period, I found out about Resilient Coders. I decided to volunteer in their afterschool program that teaches youth from communities in the Boston area how to code. Fast forward to the present, and I have worked for two years as a technology teacher at a high school in Boston and was accepted into Northeasterns Masters program in computer science.

As a Latino, activist, mental health advocate and technologist, I have learned you must have a systematic understanding of problems and issues that affect organizations, communities, and individuals, to leverage technology as a tool for social change. I am deeply passionate about exploring the use of technology to address the lack of access and inequity in education, health, and unemployment in communities of color.

content.html:
My beginnings with technology start in early childhood. During the weekends I visited my father and spent most of the time with my brother Robinson. Robinson, an electrical engineer from the Dominican Republic, was my mentor and role-model. When I visited during the weekend, I would find my brother taking apart and repairing different devices. I looked forward to spending time with him, and I would ask questions about technology, such as What is RAM?, What are the differences between AMD and Intel?. As a child, exposure to my brothers work was a valuable resource that expanded my knowledge, sparked my curiosity and interest in technology. As my skills developed, I later assisted my brother in disassembling computers, running diagnostics, installing and upgrading software.

I then attended Middle School, and a science professor was discarding a computer. I seized this opportunity and asked if I could have it, the professor donated the desktop to me. This was my first computer. I carried the large desktop up a hill and walked several blocks to my house. I troubleshot the desktop and identified the power supply wasnt working. I swapped the power supply from an abandoned computer, and voila, I became the proud owner of a Pentium II 233 MHz Desktop Computer.

Through this computer and my 56K modem, I had the worlds knowledge at my fingertips. My mind was free to explore my interests unhindered from physical and economic barriers. Having a computer enabled me to excel in my studies compared to my peers who didnt have access to one. Around the same time, I entered a summer program for Middle School students to take advanced classes and prepare them for high school level work. One of the mentors in the program offered to buy a book from a Barnes and Nobles bookstore. As the years progressed, I learned more about computers, increased my knowledge of technology and about the world.

From my experience, having access to technology or resources, advanced my learning potential. By the time I entered high school, the skills I had gained proved to be invaluable. I credit having access to a computer at a young age and having supportive mentors in shaping my path on being a self-learner. After graduating high school, I entered college to understand the problems that impact my communities, and I majored in Political Science with minors in Philosophy and Latin American Studies.

content.html:
Over the years after many conversations with friends about niche topics, staying up late at night pondering life on the verge of an existential crisis, we have arrived here a blog in 2019? Bueno, mejor que nada This post is titled Hello World, it symbolizes the first step we take to attempt to communicate with someone or something else while being simultaneously born into a new digital world of our creation.

I want you to step into my world and Ill take you with me on this journey of pursuing my masters degree in Computer Science. I see Computer Science as attaining a new ability to be able to see the world through a computational lens, the opportunity to creatively solve problems and to contribute, create and share knowledge with others.

This blog, this world thats being created will serve as a repository about what Im currently learning. I intend to share what Ive learned with others by creating content thats accessible to a wider audience. As someone who in the past has been deeply involved with community-building as a former community organizer, teacher, and mentor, I seek to bridge technology and social justice. I expect this journey to be filled with moments of joy, tears, and frustration Palante!
